avalancheActivity.comment:
The avalanche risk is moderate above the tree line and low below.
In some places, wind slab adjacent to the ridgeline can be triggered as a small slab avalanche by even a small additional load. Most avalanche prone locations are located in the north and east sectors behind terrain edges, in gullies and bowls. The risk of falling outweighs the risk of burial away from terrain traps. Also beware of stones that are only slightly covered by snow.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Pay attention to wind slabs adjacent to the ridgeline, crest or summit

snowpackStructure.comment:
By Friday evening, 10 to 20 cm of new fallen snow had fallen, with a further 5 to 10 cm falling by Saturday evening. Fresh wind slab snow is lying on top of soft new fallen snow at high altitudes, which is a weak layer. Below 1400 metres, rainfall on Friday has partially moistened the snow cover, snowpack there has formed a melt-freeze crust. The old snowpack consists of layers of faceted crystals, deep rime and melt-freeze crusts and has little tendency to break up.
Overall, there is little snow.

tendency.highlights: The wind slab remains prone to triggering. As the snowfall continues, the snowdrift accumulations will increase slightly.

weatherForecast.comment: The night to Saturday will be cloudy with light snowfall in places (maximum 5 cm of fresh snow). On Saturday, visibility will often be limited by dense clouds. In addition, light to moderate snowfall will become more frequent during the daytime changes - 5 to 10 cm will fall during the day. In Lungau, it will be mostly precipitation-free during the day, with occasional sunny spells. Brisk to strong winds from westerly directions, peaking at around 70 km/h at exposed high altitudes. Temperatures at 2000 metres around -9 degrees.

avalancheActivity.comment: The avalanche risk is moderate above the tree line and low below. In some places, wind slab adjacent to the ridgeline can be triggered as a small slab avalanche by even a small additional load. Most avalanche prone locations are in the north and east sector behind terrain edges, in gullies and bowls. The risk of falling outweighs the risk of burial away from terrain traps. Also beware of stones that are only slightly covered by snow.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Note small snowdrift accumulations adjacent to the ridgeline, crest or summit

snowpackStructure.comment: Around 10 cm of new fallen snow fell on Friday, with another 5 cm of new snow coming overnight. Soft new fallen snow overlaid by wind slabs can form a weak layer near the surface. Overall, there is little snow and there are no pronounced weak layers within the old snowpack.

tendency.highlights: The wind slab remains prone to triggering.

weatherForecast.comment: The night to Saturday will be cloudy with light snowfall in places (new snowfall of around 5 cm). During the day, the sun may also appear at times in Lungau, mostly without precipitation. Brisk to strong winds from westerly directions, peaking at around 70 km/h at exposed high altitudes. Temperatures at 2000 metres around -9 degrees.

avalancheActivity.comment:
The avalanche risk is moderate above the tree line and low below.
In some places, wind slabs adjacent to the ridgeline can be triggered by even a small additional load. Slab avalanches can reach medium size, the snowdrift accumulations grow during the daytime changes. Most avalanche prone locations are on north-west, north to south-east facing slopes, behind terrain edges, in gullies and bowls. Cracks when walking on the snow cover, snowpack indicate the danger. In addition to the risk of burial, the danger of being swept away and falling must be taken into account. There are also still many stones lurking.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Fresh wind slab prone to triggering

snowpackStructure.comment:
By Friday evening, 10 to 20 cm of new fallen snow had fallen, with a further 5 to 10 cm falling by Saturday evening. Wind and snowfall are constantly forming fresh wind slabs at altitude. The last snow to fall, surface hoar as well as faceted crystals above/below the top crust can serve as a weak layer. The rest of the old snowpack consists of layers of faceted crystals, deep rime and melt-freeze crusts and has little tendency to break up.
Below 1400 metres, rainfall moistened the snow cover on Friday, where a melt-freeze crust has formed on which the new fallen snow lies.
The amount of snow is well below average.

tendency.highlights: The wind slab remains prone to triggering. As the snowfall continues, the snowdrift accumulations will increase slightly.

weatherForecast.comment: The night to Saturday will be cloudy with light snowfall in places (maximum 5 cm of fresh snow). On Saturday, visibility will often be limited by dense clouds. In addition, light to moderate snowfall will become more frequent during the daytime changes - 5 to 10 cm will fall during the day. In Lungau, it will be mostly precipitation-free during the day, with occasional sunny spells. Brisk to strong winds from westerly directions, peaking at around 70 km/h at exposed high altitudes. Temperatures at 2000 m around -9 degrees, at 3000 m around -17 degrees.

avalancheActivity.comment:
The avalanche danger is moderate above the tree line and low below.
Slab avalanches can be triggered in some places by even a small additional load. Avalanches can reach medium size, the fresh snowdrift accumulations grow during the daytime changes. Avalanche prone locations are in north-west, east to south-facing terrain, area adjacent to the ridgeline and distant from ridgelines, behind terrain edges, in gullies and bowls. Cracks when walking on the snow cover, snowpack indicate the danger. In addition to the risk of burial, be aware of the risk of being swept away and falling. There are also still many stones lurking.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Fresh and older snowdrift accumulations are prone to disruption

snowpackStructure.comment:
By Friday evening, 10 to 20 cm of new fallen snow had fallen, with a further 5 to 10 cm falling by Saturday evening. Wind and snowfall are constantly forming fresh wind slabs at altitude. Both the soft snow that has recently fallen, surface hoar and faceted crystals above/below the uppermost crust can serve as a weak layer. The rest of the old snowpack consists of layers of faceted crystals, deep frost and melt-freeze crusts, where it has little tendency to break up.
The amount of snow is clearly below average.

tendency.highlights: The wind slab remains prone to triggering. As the snowfall continues, the snowdrift accumulations will increase slightly.

weatherForecast.comment: The night to Saturday will be cloudy with light snowfall in places (maximum 5 cm of fresh snow). On Saturday, visibility will often be limited by dense clouds. In addition, light to moderate snowfall will become more frequent during the daytime changes - 5 to 10 cm will fall during the day. In Lungau, it will be mostly precipitation-free during the day, with occasional sunny spells. Brisk to strong winds from westerly directions, peaking at around 70 km/h at exposed high altitudes. Temperatures at 2000 m around -9 degrees, at 3000 m around -17 degrees.

ALBINA.generalHeadline: Prone to triggering wind slab due to new fallen snow and wind
